description: From Middle English lusch (‚Äúslack, relaxed, limp, loose‚Äù), from Old English *lysƒã, lesƒã (‚Äúslack; limp‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *laskw, from Proto-Germanic *laskwaz (‚Äúweak, false, feeble‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *lƒìy- (‚Äúto let; leave behind‚Äù).

Akin to Old English lysu, lesu (‚Äúfalse, evil, base‚Äù), Middle Low German lasch (‚Äúslack‚Äù), Middle High German er-leswen (‚Äúto become weak‚Äù), Old Norse l«´skr (‚Äúweak, feeble‚Äù), Gothic êåªêå∞êçÉêåπêçÖêçÉ (lasiws, ‚Äúweak, feeble‚Äù), Middle Low German las, lasich (‚Äúslack, languid, idle‚Äù), Low German lusch (‚Äúloose‚Äù). Doublet of lusk. More at lishey, lazy.

entries.meaning: (dialectal) Mellow; soft; (of ground or soil) easily turned; fertile.
(of vegetation) Dense, teeming with life; luxuriant.

examples: That meal was lush! We have to go to that restaurant again sometime!
Boys with long hair are lush!

entries.meaning: (Britain, Canada, slang) Amazing, cool, fantastic, wicked.
examples: Your voice is lush, Lucy! I could listen to it all day!

description: Perhaps a humorous use of the preceding word, or perhaps from Shelta lush (‚Äúfood and drink‚Äù) (the sense "liquor" is older than the sense "drinker"). The Century Dictionary wrote that it was "said to be so called from one Lushington, a once well-known London brewer", but the Online Etymology Dictionary considers lushington (‚Äúdrinker‚Äù) a humorous extension of lush instead.

examples: Synonyms: souse, suck-pint; see also Thesaurus:drunkard

entries.meaning: (Hawaii, Pidgin, slang) A person who enjoys talking about themselves.
examples: Am I humble or am I a lush?

verbs.description: lush (third-person singular simple present lushes, present participle lushing, simple past and past participle lushed)
